path_1.title: Lethal Weapon 2 (1989)
path_1.feeling: Buddy-cop quips wear thin, but the pacing and cat-and-mouse plotting keep it passable.

path_1.title: Old Man and the Sea, The (1958)
path_1.feeling: Spare, old-fashioned perseverance tale that hits my sweet spot for classic, stoic storytelling.

path_1.title: Babe (1995)
path_1.feeling: Charming and well-made, but the cutesy animal whimsy only carries me so far.

path_1.title: Diary of a Chambermaid (Journal d'une femme de chambre, Le) (1964)
path_1.feeling: Acidic gamesmanship and sly satire leave me admiring more than enjoying.

path_1.title: Once Upon a Time in America (1984)
path_1.feeling: Grand and gloomy crime saga whose languid, self-important sprawl keeps me at arm’s length.

path_1.title: Color of Money, The (1986)
path_1.feeling: Slick pool-hall lessons with some spark, but the swagger outweighs the soul.

path_1.title: Ring, The (2002)
path_1.feeling: Gloomy supernatural dread is exactly the kind of horror I avoid.

path_1.title: Vanilla Sky (2001)
path_1.feeling: Reality-blurred melodrama that strikes me as showy rather than involving.

path_1.title: Undefeated, The (1969)
path_1.feeling: Straight-shooting Western camaraderie and wide-open vistas I can settle into.

path_1.title: Thelma & Louise (1991)
path_1.feeling: The ride has punch, but the polemical edge and spiraling bleakness keep me cool.

path_1.title: Camille Claudel (1988)
path_1.feeling: Passion and torment abound, yet the austere, drawn-out misery wears me down.

path_1.title: Beautiful Girls (1996)
path_1.feeling: Small-town musings and arrested development that feel more meandering than meaningful.

path_1.title: Best Years of Our Lives, The (1946)
path_1.feeling: Humane, clear-eyed classic that balances heart and hardship beautifully.

path_1.title: All About Eve (1950)
path_1.feeling: Razor-sharp classic drama with bite, staged and acted with real polish.

path_1.title: Mulholland Drive (2001)
path_1.feeling: Dream-logic noir that reads as opaque contrivance rather than compelling mystery to me.

path_1.title: What's Up, Tiger Lily? (1966)
path_1.feeling: The gag concept amuses in bits, but the novelty wears off quickly.

path_1.title: My Father the Hero (Mon père, ce héros.) (1991)
path_1.feeling: Awkward farce premise that never stops feeling contrived.

path_1.title: Once Upon a Time in America (1984)
path_1.feeling: Impressive in scope, yet its brooding excess keeps me distant.

path_1.title: Room with a View, A (1986)
path_1.feeling: Genteel romance and manners leave me appreciating craft more than feeling invested.

path_1.title: Apollo 13 (1995)
path_1.feeling: Clean, sturdy, inspiring procedural that scratches my admiration for competence and grit.

path_1.title: Life and Times of Judge Roy Bean, The (1972)
path_1.feeling: Quirky frontier legend with enough Western flavor to outweigh the whimsy.

path_1.title: Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys, The (2002)
path_1.feeling: Mischief and coming-of-age beats are fine, but the antics feel thin.

path_1.title: Blue Juice (1995)
path_1.feeling: Breezy surf romance that never rises above lightweight.

path_1.title: Misérables, Les (1995)
path_1.feeling: Earnest and respectable, though more dutiful than stirring for me.

path_1.title: Contact (1997)
path_1.feeling: Thoughtful, measured sci-fi that engages the head and mostly the heart.

path_1.title: Cleopatra (1963)
path_1.feeling: Old-school pageantry and palace intrigue done with grand, satisfying sweep.

path_1.title: Cyrano de Bergerac (1990)
path_1.feeling: Lyrical swashbuckling romance that hits the right classical notes for me.

path_1.title: Mississippi Masala (1991)
path_1.feeling: The cross-cultural tensions intrigue, but the romance leaves me cool.

path_2.title: Lethal Weapon 2 (1989)
path_2.feeling: Some snap and chase, but the jokey excess wears thin.

path_2.title: Old Man and the Sea, The (1958)
path_2.feeling: Spare, dignified struggle that speaks to endurance.

path_2.title: Babe (1995)
path_2.feeling: Warm, good-hearted fable that won me over more than I expected.

path_2.title: Diary of a Chambermaid (Journal d'une femme de chambre, Le) (1964)
path_2.feeling: A sardonic tangle of sex and cruelty that left me cold.

path_2.title: Once Upon a Time in America (1984)
path_2.feeling: Grandly made, but the sordid sprawl kept me at arm's length.

path_2.title: Color of Money, The (1986)
path_2.feeling: Slick hustle with decent bite, if a touch too cool.

path_2.title: Ring, The (2002)
path_2.feeling: Moody nonsense that mistakes murk for meaning.

path_2.title: Vanilla Sky (2001)
path_2.feeling: Glossy head-trip I never cared to believe in.

path_2.title: Undefeated, The (1969)
path_2.feeling: Easygoing postwar western camaraderie I enjoy.

path_2.title: Thelma & Louise (1991)
path_2.feeling: Energetic fugitive road tale, but the ethos isn't mine.

path_2.title: Camille Claudel (1988)
path_2.feeling: Well-acted anguish that feels punishing and remote.

path_2.title: Beautiful Girls (1996)
path_2.feeling: Amiable snowbound meander with thin stakes.

path_2.title: Best Years of Our Lives, The (1946)
path_2.feeling: Deeply humane homefront reckoning that moved me.

path_2.title: All About Eve (1950)
path_2.feeling: Acid, elegant backstage chess that delights.

path_2.title: Mulholland Drive (2001)
path_2.feeling: Dreamy obfuscation I found more irksome than intriguing.

path_2.title: What's Up, Tiger Lily? (1966)
path_2.feeling: A cute gag stretched far past its limits.

path_2.title: My Father the Hero (Mon père, ce héros.) (1991)
path_2.feeling: Strained farce with a premise I never warmed to.

path_2.title: Once Upon a Time in America (1984)
path_2.feeling: Impressive craft, but its bleak nostalgia left me unmoved.

path_2.title: Room with a View, A (1986)
path_2.feeling: Tasteful romance with charm, if a bit airy.

path_2.title: Apollo 13 (1995)
path_2.feeling: Sturdy, clear-eyed heroics that satisfy.

path_2.title: Life and Times of Judge Roy Bean, The (1972)
path_2.feeling: Quirky, loping western that misses my sweet spot.

path_2.title: Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys, The (2002)
path_2.feeling: Rebellious coming-of-age shenanigans that didn't land.

path_2.title: Blue Juice (1995)
path_2.feeling: Surfside dramedy that left me indifferent.

path_2.title: Misérables, Les (1995)
path_2.feeling: Earnest wartime melodrama with moments that resonate.

path_2.title: Contact (1997)
path_2.feeling: Thoughtful, idea-driven sci-fi with heart, if a tad talky.

path_2.title: Cleopatra (1963)
path_2.feeling: Lavish pageant more impressive than affecting.

path_2.title: Cyrano de Bergerac (1990)
path_2.feeling: Romantic bravado and steel with poetic heart.

path_2.title: Mississippi Masala (1991)
path_2.feeling: Sincere cross-cultural romance that never quite grabbed me.

path_2.title: Lethal Weapon 2 (1989)
path_2.feeling: Buddy-cop banter wears thin

path_2.title: Old Man and the Sea, The (1958)
path_2.feeling: Simple, stoic man-versus-sea ordeal that speaks to endurance and dignity.

path_2.title: Babe (1995)
path_2.feeling: Warm, earnest fable with real heart—sweet without tipping into saccharine.

path_2.title: Diary of a Chambermaid (Journal d'une femme de chambre, Le) (1964)

path_2.feeling: Grand, brooding crime saga whose sprawl and haze keep me at arm’s length.

path_2.title: Color of Money, The (1986)
path_2.feeling: Slick, engaging mentor-pupil dance with enough grit to hold me.

path_2.title: Ring, The (2002)

path_2.title: Vanilla Sky (2001)
path_2.feeling: Glossy mind-games and romance that blur into pretension for me.

path_2.title: Undefeated, The (1969)
path_2.feeling: Straightahead postwar western camaraderie that hits my comfort zone.

path_2.title: Thelma & Louise (1991)
path_2.feeling: Road-crime melodrama that feels more schematic than stirring.

path_2.title: Camille Claudel (1988)
path_2.feeling: Intense artistic anguish I admire in idea more than in experience.

path_2.title: Beautiful Girls (1996)
path_2.feeling: Small-town hangout talk that ambles more than it lands.

path_2.title: Best Years of Our Lives, The (1946)
path_2.feeling: Earnest, humane homefront reckoning that moves with real moral weight.

path_2.title: All About Eve (1950)
path_2.feeling: Sharp backstage chess with deliciously poised barbs and craft.

path_2.title: Mulholland Drive (2001)
path_2.feeling: Dreamy murk and narrative coyness that tries my patience.

path_2.title: What's Up, Tiger Lily? (1966)
path_2.feeling: Goofy redubbed lark—cute idea, thin returns.

path_2.title: My Father the Hero (Mon père, ce héros.) (1991)
path_2.feeling: Awkward farce that never finds a tone I can settle into.

path_2.title: Once Upon a Time in America (1984)
path_2.feeling: Impressive scope, but the melancholic sprawl keeps me distant.

path_2.title: Room with a View, A (1986)
path_2.feeling: Tidy, genteel romance with wit—pleasant if a touch airy.

path_2.title: Apollo 13 (1995)
path_2.feeling: Sturdy, procedural heroism that satisfies with clear-eyed resolve.

path_2.title: Life and Times of Judge Roy Bean, The (1972)
path_2.feeling: Quirky frontier yarn—loose, uneven, but amiable enough.

path_2.title: Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys, The (2002)
path_2.feeling: Adolescent mischief and angst that feel more contrived than lived-in.

path_2.title: Blue Juice (1995)
path_2.feeling: Surf-side fluff that never musters stakes or charm for me.

path_2.title: Misérables, Les (1995)
path_2.feeling: Wartime echoes of the novel interest me, though the drama feels patchy.

path_2.title: Contact (1997)
path_2.feeling: Thoughtful, measured sci-fi inquiry that engages my head more than my heart.

path_2.title: Cleopatra (1963)
path_2.feeling: Lavish and lumbering—spectacle I respect more than relish.

path_2.feeling: Cross-cultural romance with texture, yet the spark never quite catches for me.

path_3.title: Lethal Weapon 2 (1989)

path_3.feeling: Crisp, witty backstage scheming delivered with classic poise I relish.

path_3.title: Mulholland Drive (2001)

path_3.title: What's Up, Tiger Lily? (1966)

path_3.title: My Father the Hero (Mon père, ce héros.) (1991)
path_3.feeling: Awkward farce premise that never sits right with me.

path_3.feeling: Grand, moody crime saga whose bleak sprawl keeps me at a remove.

path_3.title: Room with a View, A (1986)

path_3.title: Apollo 13 (1995)
path_3.feeling: Clear, rousing problem-solving heroics that scratch my mission-movie itch.

path_3.title: Life and Times of Judge Roy Bean, The (1972)
path_3.feeling: Quirky, off-kilter western tall tale that’s more cute than satisfying to me.

path_3.title: Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys, The (2002)
path_3.feeling: Rowdy coming-of-age caper that’s uneven and not quite my speed.

path_3.feeling: Surfside slacker-romance stakes feel airy and forgettable to me.

path_3.title: Misérables, Les (1995)
path_3.feeling: Earnest wartime parallel to Hugo that engages me in parts without stirring me deeply.

path_3.title: Contact (1997)

path_3.title: Cleopatra (1963)
path_3.feeling: Lavish pageant with grand romance I enjoy in stretches, though it sprawls.

path_3.title: Cyrano de Bergerac (1990)

path_3.title: Mississippi Masala (1991)
path_3.feeling: Sincere cross-cultural romance that plays fine but doesn’t fully grab me.

path_3.title: Lethal Weapon 2 (1989)

path_5.title: Blue Juice (1995)
path_5.feeling: Surf-side romance and laid-back angst feel slight and dated to me.

path_5.title: Misérables, Les (1995)
path_5.feeling: Earnest parallel to Hugo that plays solid if somewhat heavy-handed.

path_5.title: Contact (1997)
path_5.feeling: Thoughtful, grounded sci-fi whose human core keeps the talk afloat.

path_5.title: Cleopatra (1963)
path_5.feeling: Grand pageant pleasures tempered by a stately, overlong march.

path_5.title: Cyrano de Bergerac (1990)
path_5.feeling: Lyrical swordplay and gallant heartbreak right in my classical wheelhouse.

path_5.title: Mississippi Masala (1991)
path_5.feeling: Cross-cultural romance with texture, though the spark is modest for me.

path_5.title: Lethal Weapon 2 (1989)
path_5.feeling: Wisecracking buddy-cop antics wore thin though the chase beats pass the time.

path_5.title: Old Man and the Sea, The (1958)
path_5.feeling: Spare, seafaring struggle hit that classical, man-against-nature chord for me.

path_5.title: Babe (1995)
path_5.feeling: Warm, old-fashioned heart and gentle humor carried me along despite the fanciful trimmings.

path_5.title: Diary of a Chambermaid (Journal d'une femme de chambre, Le) (1964)
path_5.feeling: Tart household intrigue and a dark undercurrent kept me engaged more than the sly detours.

path_5.title: Once Upon a Time in America (1984)
path_5.feeling: Grand, remorse-soaked gangster sweep impressed more than it moved me.

path_5.title: Color of Money, The (1986)
path_5.feeling: Mentor-protégé hustling and smoky poolhall rhythm held me well enough.

path_5.title: Ring, The (2002)
path_5.feeling: Supernatural dread and creepy imagery just aren’t my cup of tea.

path_5.title: Vanilla Sky (2001)
path_5.feeling: Slick mind-bending romance left me detached from its dream logic.

path_5.title: Undefeated, The (1969)
path_5.feeling: Robust, old-fashioned Western camaraderie scratched that classical itch.

path_5.title: Thelma & Louise (1991)
path_5.feeling: The fugitive momentum and loyal bond worked even when the sermonizing showed.

path_5.title: Camille Claudel (1988)
path_5.feeling: Intense artistic torment interested me more than it stirred me.

path_5.title: Beautiful Girls (1996)
path_5.feeling: Wintry small-town musings had moments, but the hangout drift felt slight.

path_5.title: Best Years of Our Lives, The (1946)
path_5.feeling: Deeply felt homecoming struggles and decency hit me squarely.

path_5.title: All About Eve (1950)
path_5.feeling: Razor-edged showbiz chess and classical bite suited me fine.

path_5.title: Mulholland Drive (2001)
path_5.feeling: Dreamlike puzzles and opaque detours left me cold.

path_5.title: What's Up, Tiger Lily? (1966)
path_5.feeling: The dubbed-goof novelty amused a bit then wore thin.

path_5.title: My Father the Hero (Mon père, ce héros.) (1991)
path_5.feeling: Awkward farce and contrived hijinks mostly put me off.

path_5.title: Once Upon a Time in America (1984)
path_5.feeling: Grand, remorse-soaked gangster sweep impressed more than it moved me.

path_5.title: Room with a View, A (1986)
path_5.feeling: Polite romance and sunlit manners pleased in parts without truly stirring me.

path_5.title: Apollo 13 (1995)
path_5.feeling: Clear, sturdy heroism and teamwork gave me a good, steady lift.

path_5.title: Life and Times of Judge Roy Bean, The (1972)
path_5.feeling: Quirky frontier justice amused in spots but felt shaggy.

path_5.title: Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys, The (2002)
path_5.feeling: Mischief and melancholy mix decently, if a bit adolescent for my taste.

path_5.title: Blue Juice (1995)
path_5.feeling: Surfside growing pains and romance felt breezy but thin.

path_5.title: Misérables, Les (1995)
path_5.feeling: The parallel-lives sweep held me more for its moral backbone than its invention.

path_5.title: Contact (1997)
path_5.feeling: Earnest wonder and debate engaged me even when the talk got heavy.

path_5.title: Cleopatra (1963)
path_5.feeling: Lavish pageantry and palace scheming entertained more than they stirred.

path_5.title: Cyrano de Bergerac (1990)
path_5.feeling: Flourish, wit, and heartbreak in classical measure hit the spot.

path_5.title: Mississippi Masala (1991)
path_5.feeling: Cross-cultural romance had warmth, though it kept me at arm’s length.

path_5.title: Lethal Weapon 2 (1989)
path_5.feeling: Buddy-cop quips and mayhem entertained in spots but felt too jokey and slick for me.

path_5.title: Old Man and the Sea, The (1958)
path_5.feeling: A quiet, classical struggle at sea that I respected and mostly felt.

path_5.title: Babe (1995)
path_5.feeling: Warm, old-fashioned heart under the modern sheen won me over.

path_5.title: Diary of a Chambermaid (Journal d'une femme de chambre, Le) (1964)
path_5.feeling: A tart, sly intrigue I admired more than I connected with.

path_5.title: Once Upon a Time in America (1984)
path_5.feeling: Grand, regret-soaked crime saga whose cool sweep kept me at some remove.

path_5.title: Color of Money, The (1986)
path_5.feeling: Sleek pool-hall hustling intrigued me without truly moving me.

path_5.title: Ring, The (2002)
path_5.feeling: Urban-legend dread and jump scares are not my cup of tea.

path_5.title: Vanilla Sky (2001)
path_5.feeling: Glossy reality-bending romance left me cold despite the ambition.

path_5.title: Undefeated, The (1969)
path_5.feeling: Sturdy, old-fashioned Western adventure scratched that classical itch.

path_5.title: Thelma & Louise (1991)
path_5.feeling: The fugitive odyssey held me, though the modern gloss kept me slightly outside.

path_5.title: Camille Claudel (1988)
path_5.feeling: Sumptuous and earnest, but the heavy, tragic churn wore me down.

path_5.title: Beautiful Girls (1996)
path_5.feeling: Small-town hangouts and mid-’90s quirk felt slight for me.

path_5.title: Best Years of Our Lives, The (1946)
path_5.feeling: Classical sweep and humane, hard-earned feeling hit me square.

path_5.title: All About Eve (1950)
path_5.feeling: Polished backstage scheming went down smooth with bite.

path_5.title: Mulholland Drive (2001)
path_5.feeling: Moody, surreal Hollywood maze kept me at a chilly distance.

path_5.title: What's Up, Tiger Lily? (1966)
path_5.feeling: Goofy redubbed caper amused in bits but felt like a sketch stretched.

path_5.title: My Father the Hero (Mon père, ce héros.) (1991)
path_5.feeling: Awkward farce premise and hijinks wore thin quickly.

path_5.title: Once Upon a Time in America (1984)
path_5.feeling: Grand, regret-soaked crime saga whose cool sweep kept me at some remove.

path_5.title: Room with a View, A (1986)
path_5.feeling: Handsome, genteel romance I could appreciate more than adore.

path_5.title: Apollo 13 (1995)
path_5.feeling: Competent, stirring craftsmanship carried me through the mission.

path_5.title: Life and Times of Judge Roy Bean, The (1972)
path_5.feeling: Roguish western antics entertained unevenly, the quirk sometimes grating.

path_5.title: Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys, The (2002)
path_5.feeling: Mischief and coming-of-age angst had truthful flickers without fully landing.

path_5.feeling: Surf-side romance and maturity jitters felt lightweight for me.

path_5.feeling: Lavish, stately pageant whose classical sweep I enjoyed despite the sprawl.

path_5.feeling: Gallant wordplay and romance pleased my classical taste, if a touch florid.

path_5.feeling: Sincere cross-cultural romance with moments that touched me, if a bit glossy.

path_5.feeling: Quippy buddy-cop mayhem kept me mildly engaged before the cartoonishness wore thin.

path_5.feeling: Spare, steadfast seafaring fable that scratched my classical itch.

path_5.feeling: Classical, heartfelt homecoming drama that moved me deeply.

path_5.feeling: Sharp, stage-world maneuvering engaged me even if the sparkle felt a touch cool.

path_5.feeling: The dubbing gimmick amused in spots before wearing thin.
